faq.a1: Prompt Party is a social network for sharing, discovering, and remixing AI prompts.
faq.a2: Yes! Prompt Party is completely free to use. You can create an account, share prompts, and build collections at no cost.
faq.a3: Yes, when creating a prompt you can choose to make it private. Private prompts are only visible to you.
faq.a4: Remixing allows you to create a new prompt based on an existing one. Your remix will credit the original creator.
faq.a5: Collections let you organize prompts into groups. You can create public collections to share with others, or private collections for personal use.
faq.a6: Prompts support full Markdown including headers, bold/italic text, code blocks, lists, links, and images.
faq.a7: Yes, you can edit or delete your prompts at any time from your profile page.
faq.a8: Trending prompts are calculated based on recent likes and comments, showing you what's popular right now.
faq.contact_text: Contact us or open an issue on our GitHub repository.

ml.analogy_dl_1: üß† Like a kid learning by watching, without explanation
ml.analogy_dl_2: üë∂ He sees tons of faces and learns on his own
ml.analogy_dl_3: üé¨ Perfect for photos, videos, sounds, text
ml.analogy_dl_4: ‚ö° But needs LOTS of examples and time
ml.analogy_ml_1: üßë‚Äçüè´ Like a coach explaining how to spot a great athlete
ml.analogy_ml_2: üë§ He tells you: 'Look at height, speed, endurance'
ml.analogy_ml_3: üìä Works well with just a few athletes as examples
ml.analogy_ml_4: üõ†Ô∏è But you need to know what to look for
ml.comparison_applications_dl: Recognize images, understand language, listen, self-driving cars
ml.comparison_computation_dl: Need SUPER powerful and special computers (GPU)
ml.comparison_cost_dl: Expensive! Need powerful servers and tons of data
ml.comparison_cost_ml: Cheap! Can do it on an old computer
ml.comparison_data_ml: Small! A few thousand is enough
ml.comparison_definition_dl: Computer learns patterns on its own without being told what to look for
ml.comparison_definition_ml: You tell the computer 'look for size and weight', and it learns on those
ml.comparison_features_ml: You must tell the computer what to look for (manual)
ml.comparison_interpretability_dl: It's mysterious - nobody knows why it decided that
ml.comparison_interpretability_ml: You can explain: 'It's small and light, so it's an apple'
ml.comparison_training_ml: Fast! A few hours or days
ml.cta_description: Now you know the difference - let's build real projects!
ml.decision_question: ‚ùì Do you have TONS of photos/videos/data?
ml.decision_yes_desc: Use Deep Learning for tasks with lots of data
ml.dl_description: When a computer learns ALL BY ITSELF how to find the rules. Like a kid learning to recognize their parents' faces without anyone explaining it.
ml.dl_limit_1: Needs TONS of examples (thousands or millions)
ml.dl_limit_2: Needs super powerful and expensive computers
ml.dl_limit_3: Mystery - nobody knows why it decided that
ml.dl_strength_1: Insanely accurate results that blow your mind
ml.dl_strength_2: Discovers the rules all on its own
ml.dl_strength_4: Works with huge amounts of data
ml.dl_use_1: ‚Ä¢ Recognize faces or objects in photos
ml.dl_use_3: ‚Ä¢ When you say "OK Google" and it understands
ml.examples_dl_1_desc: Recognizing objects in photos (cars, cats, trees), Instagram filters, self-driving cars
ml.examples_dl_2_desc: ChatGPT understanding your questions and answering, automatic translation
ml.examples_dl_3_desc: When Siri or Google Assistant understands what you say, auto-subtitles on videos
ml.examples_ml_1_desc: Banks check your income, age, job to decide if you can borrow $1000
ml.examples_ml_2_desc: Netflix or Spotify recommends movies/music based on what you watch/listen to
ml.examples_ml_3_desc: When a weird big purchase happens on your card, the bank blocks it
ml.hero_description: What's the difference between Machine Learning and Deep Learning? Discover how computers learn in two completely different ways
ml.hybrid_cv_dl: Deep Learning: Looks at a photo and figures out what's important on its own
ml.hybrid_cv_ml: Machine Learning: Then we tell it 'Now decide if it's a cat or a dog'
ml.hybrid_cv_solution: Result: DL sees the details, ML judges fast - super efficient!
ml.hybrid_nlp_dl: Deep Learning: Understands what the text means and the context
ml.hybrid_nlp_ml: Machine Learning: Makes a quick decision based on that
ml.hybrid_nlp_solution: Result: Faster and smarter than just using DL alone
ml.hybrid_subtitle: Often the two together is better than one alone!
ml.hybrid_title: üöÄ The Best Solution: Mix ML and DL
ml.ml_description: Teaching a computer to make decisions by showing it examples. Like teaching someone to recognize an apple by showing them 100 different apples.
ml.ml_limit_1: You have to tell it what to look for
ml.ml_limit_2: Needs an expert to set up
ml.ml_strength_4: You can explain why it decided that
ml.ml_use_1: ‚Ä¢ Decide if someone can get a loan
ml.page_description: Complete guide to understanding the differences between Machine Learning and Deep Learning, when to use each, and how to combine them
ml.page_title: Machine Learning vs Deep Learning | Prompt Party

mcp_integration.what_is_mcp_text: The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open standard that enables AI models and assistants to securely access external data sources and tools. Prompt Party's MCP endpoint provides structured access to our prompt library, allowing AI assistants to discover, search, and retrieve prompts programmatically.

claude_basics.claude_intro: is an advanced AI assistant created by Anthropic, designed to be helpful, harmless, and honest. It can assist with a wide variety of tasks including writing, analysis, math, coding, and creative work.
claude_basics.large_context_desc: Claude can process and understand large amounts of text, allowing you to:
claude_basics.context_3: Reference multiple sources in one prompt
claude_basics.safety_desc: Claude is built with safety in mind and designed to refuse harmful requests while being genuinely helpful with legitimate ones.
claude_basics.reasoning_desc: Claude can break down complex problems, explain its thinking process, and provide detailed reasoning for its responses.
claude_basics.tip_text: The more context and detail you provide, the better Claude can assist you. Think of Claude as a colleague who benefits from clear instructions and background information.
claude_basics.too_vague: This prompt is too vague. Claude won't know your tech stack, project requirements, or what you've already tried.
claude_basics.within_desc: Claude remembers everything you've said earlier in the conversation. You can reference previous messages and Claude will understand the context.
claude_basics.between_desc: Claude does not remember previous conversations. Each conversation starts fresh. If you need to reference earlier discussions, you'll need to include that context in your current conversation.
claude_basics.context_tip: When starting a new conversation, provide relevant context from your previous discussions if needed.
claude_basics.do_1: Be specific and clear about what you want
claude_basics.do_3: Break down complex tasks into steps
claude_basics.do_4: Ask Claude to explain its reasoning
claude_basics.do_5: Iterate and refine based on responses
claude_basics.avoid_3: Asking for harmful or unethical content
claude_basics.avoid_4: Treating Claude as a search engine
claude_basics.practice_starters: Try these prompt templates to practice

intro_prompts.title: Introduction to AI Prompts
intro_prompts.subtitle: Learn the fundamentals of AI prompting
intro_prompts.page_description: Master the basics of AI prompting
intro_prompts.what_is_prompt_intro: An AI prompt is a text instruction you give to an AI model to generate a specific output.
intro_prompts.vague_description: Lacks clarity on subject, format, and purpose
intro_prompts.specific_example: Write a 500-word blog post about the history of Egyptian cats with historical facts
intro_prompts.specific_description: Clearly specifies format, length, and subject
intro_prompts.anatomy_title: The Anatomy of a Good Prompt
intro_prompts.element_context_desc: Provide context and background to help the AI understand your request
intro_prompts.element_context_example: I am a marketing manager for a tech startup
intro_prompts.element_task_desc: Clearly explain what you want the AI to do
intro_prompts.element_constraints_desc: Define limits and requirements (length, tone, format)
intro_prompts.element_constraints_example: Each idea max 280 characters. Tone: professional but friendly
intro_prompts.element_format_desc: Specify the output format you want (list, JSON, table)
intro_prompts.element_format_example: Return as a bulleted list with titles and descriptions
intro_prompts.mistake1_good: Write a 200-word LinkedIn post about AI in marketing for B2B SaaS
intro_prompts.mistake2_good: Give me 5 content ideas as a JSON array with title and description
intro_prompts.mistake3_good: Analyze this customer feedback for a B2B SaaS product
intro_prompts.mistake3_note: Always provide context about who, what, and why
intro_prompts.template_writing_desc: Use this for blog posts, emails, social content
intro_prompts.template_writing_code: I am a [role]. Write a [type] about [topic] in [tone].
intro_prompts.template_analysis_desc: Use this for reviews, summaries, classifications
intro_prompts.template_code_desc: Use this for code generation and debugging
intro_prompts.template_learning_desc: Use this to explain concepts or teach topics
intro_prompts.exercise1_prompt: Transform this vague prompt into a specific one: 'Write something funny'
intro_prompts.exercise1_hint: Include format, tone, topic, and length
intro_prompts.exercise2_prompt: Improve this prompt by adding context: 'Generate marketing copy'
intro_prompts.exercise2_hint: Who is the audience? What product? What's the goal?
intro_prompts.exercise3_prompt: Create a complete prompt for generating a technical blog post about prompt engineering
intro_prompts.exercise3_hint: Use the template and include all elements
intro_prompts.pro_tip: Pro Tip: The more specific and detailed your prompt, the better the AI can understand and deliver what you need.

prompt_templates.page_description: Learn how to create and customize prompt templates. Master ready-to-use templates for common AI tasks.
prompt_templates.title: Prompt Templates
prompt_templates.subtitle: Master ready-to-use templates for consistent, high-quality AI outputs
prompt_templates.learn_what: What prompt templates are and why they matter
prompt_templates.learn_create: How to create effective templates for your needs
prompt_templates.learn_customize: How to customize templates for specific use cases
prompt_templates.template_intro: A prompt template is a reusable structure you fill with specific information to create consistent, high-quality prompts. Instead of writing prompts from scratch every time, templates help you maintain quality and save time.
prompt_templates.anatomy_1_desc: Parts in [BRACKETS] that you replace with specific information. Example: [TOPIC], [TONE], [AUDIENCE]
prompt_templates.anatomy_2_desc: The main action or task description that stays consistent. Example: 'Write a...', 'Analyze...', 'Generate...'
prompt_templates.anatomy_3_desc: Define the output format to ensure consistency. Example: 'Return as JSON', 'Use bullet points', 'Include headings'
prompt_templates.anatomy_4_desc: Set boundaries for tone, length, style, or other parameters to control quality and consistency
prompt_templates.placeholder_tip: Use clear [VARIABLE] names to make templates easy to use. Avoid ambiguous names like [X] or [DATA].
prompt_templates.email_desc: Generate professional emails for any purpose
prompt_templates.code_review_desc: Get comprehensive code reviews with structured feedback
prompt_templates.social_media_desc: Create engaging posts for any platform
prompt_templates.learning_desc: Explain complex topics in an easy-to-understand way
prompt_templates.problem_solving_desc: Get structured solutions for any challenge
prompt_templates.mix_match_desc: Combine different template parts to create hybrid templates that suit your specific needs.
prompt_templates.domain_desc: Tailor templates for specific industries, roles, or use cases. Example: a marketing template might have different constraints than a technical template.
prompt_templates.save_desc: Keep a collection of templates that work well for you. Over time, you'll build a library of high-performing templates.
prompt_templates.share_desc: Share effective templates with teammates to standardize outputs across your organization.
prompt_templates.nested_desc: Templates that include other templates as components. This creates powerful, multi-level structures for complex tasks.
prompt_templates.conditional_desc: Use 'IF' logic to adapt prompts based on conditions. Example: [IF TECHNICAL: Include code examples]
prompt_templates.variables_desc: Use variables with default values to make templates more flexible. Variables can have fallback values if not specified.
prompt_templates.create_your_own: Practice Exercise: Create Your Own Template
prompt_templates.practice_text: Now it's time to create your first template. Think about a task you frequently give to AI. Design a template that could make that task faster and more consistent.
prompt_templates.step_1: Choose a recurring task you want to automate with a template
prompt_templates.step_2: Identify the key variables that change each time (put them in [BRACKETS])
prompt_templates.step_3: Write the core instructions that stay the same
prompt_templates.step_4: Add format specifications to ensure consistent output
prompt_templates.step_5: Test your template with 2-3 different sets of variables
prompt_templates.challenge_text: Create a template for your most frequently used prompt and share it with others!

claude_code_basics.section_1_intro: Claude Code is an AI-powered development assistant that understands your project context and generates code following your established patterns and conventions.
claude_code_basics.section_1_feature_1_desc: Reads your CLAUDE.md and understands your project structure, tech stack, and coding standards
claude_code_basics.section_1_feature_2_desc: Refactors existing code while maintaining TypeScript safety and design patterns
claude_code_basics.section_1_feature_3_desc: Identifies bugs and suggests fixes with full understanding of your codebase
claude_code_basics.section_1_feature_4_desc: Creates comprehensive documentation aligned with your project standards
claude_code_basics.vs_copilot_desc: Unlike Copilot which works at the file level, Claude Code understands your entire project context including architecture, conventions, and business logic.
claude_code_basics.section_2_cloud_desc: Access Claude Code directly from your browser with cloud-based development
claude_code_basics.section_2_cli_desc: Install the Claude Code CLI for local development with full terminal integration
claude_code_basics.section_2_github_desc: Link your GitHub repository for seamless repository access and context
claude_code_basics.section_2_github_step_1: Create a CLAUDE.md file in your repository root
claude_code_basics.section_2_github_step_2: Add project overview, tech stack, and coding standards
claude_code_basics.section_2_github_step_3: Authenticate Claude Code with your GitHub account
claude_code_basics.section_2_claude_md_desc: Your CLAUDE.md is the foundation for context-aware AI development
claude_code_basics.section_3_tip: Start with simple requests before moving to complex features. The more context you provide, the better Claude Code performs.
claude_code_basics.section_3_refactoring_desc: Ask Claude Code to improve existing code by refactoring patterns, extracting utilities, or optimizing performance
claude_code_basics.section_3_debugging_desc: Share error messages and code context. Claude Code will identify root causes and suggest fixes
claude_code_basics.section_4_example_1_desc: Generate a complete responsive dashboard with sidebar, header, and main content area
claude_code_basics.section_4_example_result: Result: Production-ready component with TypeScript types and Tailwind styling
claude_code_basics.section_4_example_2_desc: Migrate state management from Redux with less boilerplate and better types
claude_code_basics.section_4_example_3_desc: Create a complete API with authentication, rate limiting, and error handling
claude_code_basics.do_1: Provide clear, specific requirements with context
claude_code_basics.do_4: Use Claude Code for architecture decisions
claude_code_basics.do_5: Integrate into your team's workflow gradually
claude_code_basics.avoid_3: Using Claude Code for business logic design alone
claude_code_basics.avoid_4: Blindly trusting generated code without review
claude_code_basics.section_5_integration_2: Use code review as a learning tool
claude_code_basics.section_5_integration_3: Share successful prompts with your team
claude_code_basics.section_6_pitfall_1_desc: Claude Code is a tool, not a replacement for developer expertise. Always review and understand generated code.
claude_code_basics.section_6_pitfall_2_desc: If your CLAUDE.md is outdated or incomplete, Claude Code won't understand your project properly. Keep it updated.
claude_code_basics.section_6_pitfall_3_desc: Claude Code generates code that needs security review. Never merge untested code to production.
claude_code_basics.section_6_limitation_1: Cannot modify infrastructure or deployment configuration
claude_code_basics.section_6_limitation_2: Needs clear business logic explanation for complex algorithms
claude_code_basics.section_6_limitation_3: May generate code requiring significant refactoring
claude_code_basics.quiz_good: Good! You understand Claude Code well.
claude_code_basics.quiz_review: Review the material and try again.
claude_code_basics.quiz_q1: What is the primary benefit of Claude Code over GitHub Copilot?
claude_code_basics.quiz_q1_o1: It understands your entire project context and follows your conventions
claude_code_basics.quiz_q1_exp: Claude Code uniquely understands your project architecture through CLAUDE.md
claude_code_basics.quiz_q2_o3: Providing context to Claude Code about your project
claude_code_basics.quiz_q2_exp: CLAUDE.md contains project overview, tech stack, and coding standards
claude_code_basics.quiz_q3: How should you use Claude Code-generated code?
claude_code_basics.quiz_q3_o2: Review and understand it before merging
claude_code_basics.quiz_q3_o3: Use it only as a reference
claude_code_basics.quiz_q3_exp: Always review generated code for correctness and security
claude_code_basics.quiz_q4: What's the best way to structure a Claude Code request?
claude_code_basics.quiz_q4_o1: Be specific with requirements and provide context
claude_code_basics.quiz_q4_o2: Use vague descriptions to encourage creativity
claude_code_basics.quiz_q4_o3: Ask for features without explaining the use case
claude_code_basics.quiz_q4_o4: Request multiple unrelated features at once
claude_code_basics.quiz_q4_exp: Clear, specific requests with context produce better results
claude_code_basics.quiz_q5: Which is NOT a recommended use case for Claude Code?
claude_code_basics.quiz_q5_exp: Claude Code should assist in decisions, not make them independently
claude_code_basics.quiz_q6: How should you handle security with Claude Code?
claude_code_basics.quiz_q6_o2: Always review code for security vulnerabilities
claude_code_basics.quiz_q6_o3: Only use Claude Code for non-sensitive code
claude_code_basics.quiz_q6_exp: Security review is essential for all generated code
claude_code_basics.quiz_q7: What should happen when Claude Code doesn't understand your code?
claude_code_basics.quiz_q7_o1: Give up and manually write the code
claude_code_basics.quiz_q7_o2: Improve your CLAUDE.md or provide more context
claude_code_basics.quiz_q7_exp: Better context in CLAUDE.md improves Claude Code's understanding
claude_code_basics.quiz_q8: Can Claude Code refactor your entire codebase at once?
claude_code_basics.quiz_q8_o1: Yes, but review the results carefully
claude_code_basics.quiz_q8_o2: Only refactor one file at a time
claude_code_basics.quiz_q8_exp: Gradual refactoring with review is safer than large-scale automated changes
claude_code_basics.quiz_q9: What's the best team practice with Claude Code?
claude_code_basics.quiz_q9_o1: Only let senior developers use it
claude_code_basics.quiz_q9_o2: Create team guidelines and share successful prompts
claude_code_basics.quiz_q9_o3: Never use it in a team setting
claude_code_basics.quiz_q9_exp: Team guidelines and shared knowledge maximize Claude Code benefits

claude_code_basics.quiz_q10_o2: Every major update to the project
claude_code_basics.quiz_q10_exp: Keep CLAUDE.md updated to maintain Claude Code's accuracy

quiz.q1_question: What is the primary benefit of Claude Code over GitHub Copilot?
quiz.q1_option_1: It understands your entire project context and follows your conventions
quiz.q1_explanation: Claude Code uniquely understands your project architecture through CLAUDE.md and maintains consistency with your coding standards.
quiz.q2_question: What is the purpose of CLAUDE.md?
quiz.q2_option_2: Project context guide for Claude Code to understand your conventions
quiz.q2_explanation: CLAUDE.md is Claude Code's instruction manual, containing your project overview, tech stack, architecture, and coding standards.
quiz.q3_question: Which of the following is a good use case for Claude Code?
quiz.q3_option_1: Generating a production dashboard with TypeScript and Tailwind CSS
quiz.q3_option_2: Designing business logic for a new feature
quiz.q3_explanation: Claude Code excels at code generation and refactoring. For business logic design, you should provide clear specifications first.
quiz.q4_question: What should you always do before merging Claude Code generated code?
quiz.q4_option_3: Review the code thoroughly and understand what it does
quiz.q4_option_4: Test it with dummy data only
quiz.q4_explanation: Always review generated code to ensure it meets your requirements, follows best practices, and has no security issues.
quiz.q5_question: How does Claude Code handle project context?
quiz.q5_option_1: By reading individual files one at a time
quiz.q5_option_3: By using information from CLAUDE.md and your project structure
quiz.q5_option_4: It doesn't need context to generate code
quiz.q5_explanation: Claude Code reads your CLAUDE.md and understands your project structure to maintain consistency with your established patterns.
quiz.q6_question: What is a limitation of Claude Code?
quiz.q6_option_2: It cannot modify infrastructure or deployment configuration
quiz.q6_option_3: It only works with React projects
quiz.q6_option_4: It requires internet connection for each request
quiz.q6_explanation: Claude Code has clear limitations including not being able to modify infrastructure, deploy applications, or handle deployment configs directly.
quiz.q7_question: When should you update your CLAUDE.md?
quiz.q7_option_1: Only when you add new team members
quiz.q7_option_3: Whenever your tech stack, architecture, or conventions change
quiz.q7_explanation: Keep CLAUDE.md updated whenever your project changes. An outdated guide means Claude Code won't understand your current conventions.
quiz.q8_question: Which of these is a best practice when using Claude Code?
quiz.q8_option_1: Provide vague requests to test the AI
quiz.q8_option_2: Provide clear, specific requirements with full context
quiz.q8_option_4: Skip code review to save time
quiz.q8_explanation: Clear, specific requirements with proper context lead to better code generation. Always reference your CLAUDE.md and review generated code.
quiz.q9_question: What can Claude Code help you with?
quiz.q9_option_3: All of the above - generation, refactoring, debugging, and architecture discussions
quiz.q9_explanation: Claude Code is versatile - it helps with generation, refactoring, debugging, and serving as a sounding board for architecture decisions.
quiz.q10_question: How should Claude Code be integrated into your team's workflow?
quiz.q10_option_1: Replace all developers with Claude Code
quiz.q10_option_2: Never use it, stick to manual coding
quiz.q10_option_3: Gradually integrate it, use code reviews as learning opportunities
quiz.q10_option_4: Use it only for trivial tasks
quiz.q10_explanation: Gradually introduce Claude Code, use it as a productivity tool, and leverage code reviews to learn from AI-generated code.

ragas_evaluation.page_title: Ragas Prompt Evaluation | Master Quality Metrics
ragas_evaluation.page_description: Learn Ragas framework for evaluating AI prompt quality. Master metrics, setup, CLI usage, code integration, and real-world examples.
ragas_evaluation.title: Ragas Prompt Evaluation
ragas_evaluation.subtitle: Systematically measure and improve your AI prompt quality
ragas_evaluation.learn_1: Understand prompt quality metrics and their importance
ragas_evaluation.learn_2: Install and configure Ragas with your LLM provider
ragas_evaluation.learn_3: Use Ragas CLI and Python API for evaluation
ragas_evaluation.learn_4: Integrate Ragas into your CI/CD pipeline
ragas_evaluation.section_1_intro: Prompt quality directly impacts AI output quality. Ragas provides scientific metrics to measure and improve this quality systematically.
ragas_evaluation.section_1_benefit_1_desc: Measure prompt effectiveness before deploying to production
ragas_evaluation.section_1_benefit_2_desc: Monitor how your prompts improve over time
ragas_evaluation.section_1_benefit_3_desc: Make optimization choices based on metrics, not guesswork
ragas_evaluation.section_1_benefit_4_desc: Catch prompt failures before they reach production
ragas_evaluation.section_1_stat_desc: Teams using Ragas report 40% fewer prompt-related incidents in production.
ragas_evaluation.section_2_metric_1_desc: Measures factual accuracy: does the AI response stick to the facts in the context?
ragas_evaluation.section_2_metric_1_example:
Prompt: 'Summarize this article'
Context: 'The company was founded in 2020'
Good Response: 'Founded in 2020' (Faithfulness: 1.0)
Bad Response: 'Founded in 2015' (Faithfulness: 0.0)
ragas_evaluation.section_2_metric_2_desc: Evaluates how relevant the response is to the original question
ragas_evaluation.section_2_metric_2_formula: Relevancy Score = Cosine Similarity(Question Embedding, Answer Embedding)
ragas_evaluation.section_2_metric_2_example:
Prompt: 'What is the capital of France?'
Good Response: 'Paris is the capital' (Relevancy: 0.95)
Bad Response: 'France is a country in Europe' (Relevancy: 0.6)
ragas_evaluation.section_2_metric_3_desc: Measures the quality and relevance of the retrieved context
ragas_evaluation.section_2_metric_3_formula: Precision = (Relevant Context Chunks / Total Context Chunks)
ragas_evaluation.section_2_metric_4_desc: Measures how much relevant context was retrieved
ragas_evaluation.section_2_metric_4_formula: Recall = (Retrieved Relevant Chunks / All Relevant Chunks)
ragas_evaluation.section_2_metric_5_desc: Compares expected output with actual output using embeddings
ragas_evaluation.section_3_config_desc: Ragas works with OpenAI, Anthropic (Claude), Cohere, local models via Ollama, and more.
ragas_evaluation.section_3_tip: Ragas can evaluate prompts using different LLM providers. Choose the one that matches your production environment for best results.
ragas_evaluation.section_4_evaluate_desc: Evaluate a single prompt with context and expected response
ragas_evaluation.section_4_batch_desc: Evaluate multiple prompts at once using a JSON file
ragas_evaluation.section_6_example_1_desc: Evaluate if your summarization prompt extracts key facts accurately
ragas_evaluation.section_6_example_3_desc: Assess creative prompt quality and coherence
ragas_evaluation.quiz_q1_exp: Ragas is specifically designed for evaluating AI prompt quality
ragas_evaluation.quiz_q2: What's a good Faithfulness score threshold?
ragas_evaluation.quiz_q2_exp: Generally, 0.7+ is considered good for production use
ragas_evaluation.quiz_q3_exp: Context Recall specifically measures completeness of context retrieval

spec_driven_development.section_1_principle_3_desc: Developers know exactly what to build
spec_driven_development.section_1_principle_4_desc: Clear success criteria make testing straightforward
spec_driven_development.section_2_intro: Follow this proven workflow to implement spec-driven development in your projects:
spec_driven_development.section_3_clarity_desc: Write specifications in plain language that everyone can understand. Avoid vague terminology and be specific about requirements.
spec_driven_development.section_3_examples_desc: Provide concrete examples of expected behavior. Show what good looks like and what to avoid.
spec_driven_development.section_3_tip: Use the specification as a contract between stakeholders
spec_driven_development.section_4_issues_desc: Create GitHub issues with 'spec' label for feature specifications, including all sections of your specification template
spec_driven_development.section_4_pr_desc: Reference specification issues in PR descriptions to maintain traceability and ensure implementation follows the spec
spec_driven_development.section_5_dont_2: Specs that are too long or too short
spec_driven_development.section_6_pitfall_1_desc: Lack of detail leads to misunderstandings and rework
spec_driven_development.section_6_pitfall_2_desc: Too much detail can slow down development unnecessarily
spec_driven_development.section_6_pitfall_3_desc: Specs are only useful if developers actually follow them
spec_driven_development.section_7_example_intro: Here's a real specification used at Prompt Party to define the favorites feature:
spec_driven_development.section_8_review_desc: Establish a formal review process where the team discusses and approves specs before implementation begins
spec_driven_development.section_8_communication_desc: Use specs as the single source of truth. Reference them in discussions, PRs, and code reviews.
spec_driven_development.section_8_updates_desc: When requirements change, update the spec and re-discuss with the team

tutorials.complete_quiz_tip: Complete the quiz at the end to validate this lesson
tutorials.quiz_validation_description: Answer the questions to complete this lesson
tutorials.quiz_partial_answers: You got {score} out of {totalQuestions} answers correct

claudeAgents.page_title: Claude Agents | Build Autonomous AI Agents
claudeAgents.page_description: Learn how to build autonomous AI agents with Claude. Master tool use, agent design, and advanced patterns.
claudeAgents.title: Building Claude Agents
claudeAgents.description: Create autonomous AI agents that can use tools and solve complex problems
claudeAgents.learn_tool_use: How to define and use tools with Claude
claudeAgents.intro_para1: Claude agents are AI systems that can autonomously decide when and how to use tools to accomplish goals. Unlike simple API calls, agents can reason about their tasks, use multiple tools in sequence, and adapt their behavior based on results.
claudeAgents.intro_capability1: Autonomously choose which tools to use
claudeAgents.intro_capability2: Reason about tool outputs and plan next steps
claudeAgents.intro_capability4: Recover from errors and retry with different approaches
claudeAgents.intro_capability5: Integrate with external APIs and services
claudeAgents.intro_para2: Let's explore how to build agents step by step, starting with tool definitions and moving to complete agent implementations.
claudeAgents.tool_defining_description: Tools are defined with JSON schemas that describe their inputs and outputs
claudeAgents.agent_loop_description: The core pattern: Claude responds, if it wants a tool, execute it, feed results back, repeat until done
claudeAgents.tool_functions_description: Create functions that execute the actual tool logic and return results
claudeAgents.advanced_multi_step_description: Chain multiple tools together to solve complex problems requiring sequential steps
claudeAgents.advanced_error_handling_description: Gracefully handle tool failures and provide feedback to the agent
claudeAgents.best_practices_do2: Define precise input schemas with validation
claudeAgents.best_practices_do3: Test tools independently before using with agents
claudeAgents.best_practices_do4: Implement proper error handling and logging
claudeAgents.best_practices_do5: Use system prompts to guide agent behavior
claudeAgents.best_practices_do6: Monitor and log agent interactions for debugging
claudeAgents.best_practices_dont1: Don't create tools without clear purposes or documentation
claudeAgents.best_practices_dont2: Don't allow unlimited tool retries without safeguards
claudeAgents.best_practices_dont3: Don't expose sensitive data through tool outputs
claudeAgents.best_practices_dont5: Don't skip input validation in tool implementations
claudeAgents.example_card_description: A practical agent that searches the web and synthesizes research findings
claudeAgents.alert_input_schema_text: tells Claude what parameters a tool accepts. Well-defined schemas help Claude understand how to use your tools correctly.

advanced_prompting.page_title: Advanced Prompting Techniques | Tutorials | Prompt Party
advanced_prompting.page_description: Learn chain-of-thought, few-shot learning, role-based prompting and other advanced techniques.
advanced_prompting.title: Advanced Prompting Techniques
advanced_prompting.subtitle: Master chain-of-thought, few-shot learning, role-based prompting, and more.
advanced_prompting.cot_intro: Chain-of-thought prompting encourages the AI to show its reasoning process step-by-step, leading to more accurate and explainable results.
advanced_prompting.without_cot_desc: Direct answer without explanation. Harder to verify or learn from.
advanced_prompting.with_cot_desc: Clear reasoning process. Easy to verify and understand.
advanced_prompting.few_shot_intro: Provide examples of the desired input-output pattern to guide the AI's responses.
advanced_prompting.few_shot_pattern_desc: Show 2-3 examples before your actual request
advanced_prompting.few_shot_tip: 2-5 examples usually work best. Too few and the pattern isn't clear. Too many and you waste tokens!
advanced_prompting.role_prompting_intro: Assign a specific role or persona to the AI to get responses aligned with that perspective and expertise.
advanced_prompting.meta_prompting_intro: Ask the AI to help you create or improve prompts. The AI becomes your prompting assistant!
advanced_prompting.refinement_step_2: Identify what is missing or wrong
advanced_prompting.refinement_step_3_desc: This is good, but could you also...
advanced_prompting.constraints_intro: Constraints can paradoxically improve creativity and output quality:
advanced_prompting.practice_intro: Combine at least 3 techniques from this tutorial to create a prompt for:
advanced_prompting.practice_task: Create a product description for a new smartphone that appeals to both tech enthusiasts and casual users.
advanced_prompting.practice_hint: Hint: Try combining role-based prompting + few-shot examples + constraints!

ml_basics.page_title: Machine Learning Basics | Understand ML Fundamentals
ml_basics.page_description: Learn machine learning concepts, training data preparation, and model evaluation techniques.
ml_basics.title: ML Basics
ml_basics.subtitle: Understand machine learning fundamentals and core concepts
ml_basics.learn_data: How to prepare and clean training data
ml_basics.learn_evaluation: How to evaluate and measure model performance
ml_basics.ml_intro: Machine Learning is a subset of AI that enables computers to learn from data without being explicitly programmed. Instead of following fixed rules, ML systems improve their performance through experience and examples.
ml_basics.supervised_desc: Learning from labeled data with known outputs to predict future outcomes
ml_basics.unsupervised_desc: Finding patterns in unlabeled data without predefined outputs
ml_basics.data_intro: Quality data is the foundation of any successful ML model. Poor data leads to poor predictions, no matter how sophisticated your algorithm is.
ml_basics.data_quality_desc: Garbage in, garbage out. The quality of your training data directly impacts model performance.
ml_basics.data_cleaning_desc: Remove duplicates, handle missing values, and fix inconsistencies in your dataset.
ml_basics.data_normalization_desc: Scale features to similar ranges to help algorithms learn more effectively.
ml_basics.data_splitting_desc: Divide data into training and test sets to prevent overfitting and accurately measure performance.
ml_basics.training_intro: Training is the process where the model learns patterns from data by adjusting its parameters to minimize error.
ml_basics.overfitting_desc: Overfitting happens when a model learns the training data too well, including its noise, and performs poorly on new data.
ml_basics.evaluation_intro: Evaluating your model is crucial to understand how well it will perform on unseen data. Use appropriate metrics for your task.
ml_basics.accuracy_desc: Percentage of correct predictions. Good for balanced datasets, but can be misleading for imbalanced data.
ml_basics.precision_desc: Of the positive predictions, how many were correct? Important when false positives are costly.
ml_basics.recall_desc: Of the actual positives, how many did we find? Important when false negatives are costly.
ml_basics.f1_score_desc: Harmonic mean of precision and recall. Ideal for imbalanced classification problems.
ml_basics.practice_intro: Put your knowledge to the test:
ml_basics.practice_task: Analyze a dataset of house prices with features like size, location, and age. What preprocessing steps would you take? How would you split the data? What metric would you use?
ml_basics.practice_hint: Hint: Think about feature scaling, handling missing values, and appropriate train/test split ratios.

data_fundamentals.page_title: Data Fundamentals for AI | Understanding Data Quality
data_fundamentals.page_description: Learn about data types, preprocessing techniques, train/test splits, and data quality assessment for machine learning.
data_fundamentals.title: Data Fundamentals for AI
data_fundamentals.subtitle: Master the critical role of data quality in AI model performance
data_fundamentals.learn_data_types: Understanding different data types and their characteristics
data_fundamentals.learn_preprocessing: Master data preprocessing and cleaning techniques
data_fundamentals.learn_splits: Learn about train/validation/test data splitting strategies
data_fundamentals.learn_quality: Identify and mitigate data quality issues and bias
data_fundamentals.data_foundation: Data is the foundation of any successful machine learning model. The quality, quantity, and characteristics of your training data directly impact model performance. Poor data leads to poor predictions, regardless of how sophisticated your algorithm is. Understanding data fundamentals is essential before building any AI system.
data_fundamentals.garbage_in_desc: If your training data is biased, incomplete, or noisy, your model will learn those problems.
data_fundamentals.quality_matters_desc: 100 high-quality, representative examples are often better than 10,000 biased or noisy ones.
data_fundamentals.tip_data_quality: Always spend time understanding and cleaning your data before training models. This often saves time and produces better results than tweaking algorithms.
data_fundamentals.data_types_intro: Different data types require different preprocessing and handling approaches. Let's explore the main categories.
data_fundamentals.structured_data_desc: Organized in rows and columns, typically in databases or CSV files.
data_fundamentals.structured_ex_1: Customer purchase records in a database
data_fundamentals.unstructured_data_desc: Raw data without predefined structure, requiring special preprocessing.
data_fundamentals.unstructured_ex_1: Text documents, articles, social media posts
data_fundamentals.timeseries_data_desc: Data points ordered by time, where temporal order matters.
data_fundamentals.preprocessing_intro: Before training any model, raw data must go through a preprocessing pipeline. This is often 70% of the work in machine learning projects.
data_fundamentals.cleaning_desc: Remove errors, inconsistencies, and problematic entries from your dataset.
data_fundamentals.cleaning_1: Handle missing values (delete, impute, or flag)
data_fundamentals.cleaning_2: Remove or correct outliers and errors
data_fundamentals.normalization_desc: Transform features to similar ranges so algorithms learn effectively.
data_fundamentals.feature_eng_desc: Create new features or transform existing ones to improve model performance.
data_fundamentals.feature_eng_1: Combining existing features into new ones
data_fundamentals.feature_eng_2: Extracting temporal features (day of week, hour)
data_fundamentals.tip_preprocessing: Use a consistent preprocessing pipeline and apply the same transformations to all data splits. Fit preprocessing parameters only on training data to avoid data leakage.
data_fundamentals.train_test_split_intro: Separating your data into train, validation, and test sets prevents overfitting and provides honest performance estimates.
data_fundamentals.split_ratio_1_desc: Traditional approach: 70% training, 15% validation, 15% test. Good for medium-sized datasets.
data_fundamentals.split_ratio_2_desc: Emphasizes training: 80% training, 10% validation, 10% test. Use with larger datasets.
data_fundamentals.split_ratio_3_desc: K-fold cross-validation for small datasets: divide data into k parts, train k times using each part as test.
data_fundamentals.random_sampling_desc: Simple random selection of train/test samples. Works well when data is balanced, but can create imbalanced splits.
data_fundamentals.stratified_sampling_desc: Maintains class proportions in each split. Essential for imbalanced datasets where some classes are rare.
data_fundamentals.data_quality_intro: Beyond preprocessing, be aware of these common data quality issues that can ruin model performance.
data_fundamentals.bias_desc: Historical bias in training data (e.g., all examples of 'doctor' are male) causes models to learn and perpetuate bias. Requires careful data collection and balancing.
data_fundamentals.imbalance_desc: When one class heavily outnumbers others (95% negative, 5% positive), models can achieve high accuracy by ignoring the minority class. Use stratified sampling and appropriate metrics.
data_fundamentals.leakage_desc: Information from test set accidentally influences training, causing unrealistically high performance estimates that don't generalize. Always split data before preprocessing.
data_fundamentals.tip_quality: Create a data quality checklist: What percent of values are missing? Is there temporal distribution shift? Are all classes represented? Document known limitations and biases.
data_fundamentals.exercise_title: Try It Yourself: Data Analysis Challenge
data_fundamentals.exercise_1_desc: Analyze a dataset with missing values, duplicates, and outliers. Write a prompt for Claude to help you identify issues and propose preprocessing steps.
data_fundamentals.exercise_2_desc: For a sentiment analysis dataset of 10,000 movie reviews, design an appropriate train/val/test split strategy and justify your choices.
data_fundamentals.exercise_3_desc: Examine a sample dataset for potential sources of bias. What groups might be underrepresented? How would you address these issues?
data_fundamentals.quiz_intro: Test your understanding of data fundamentals with our interactive quiz:
data_fundamentals.next_steps_desc: Ready to learn more? Continue your learning journey with these related tutorials:

dl_fundamentals.page_title: Deep Learning Fundamentals | Master Neural Networks
dl_fundamentals.page_description: Learn neural networks, backpropagation, and modern deep learning architectures like CNNs, RNNs, and Transformers.
dl_fundamentals.title: Deep Learning Fundamentals
dl_fundamentals.subtitle: Master neural networks and modern deep learning architectures
dl_fundamentals.learn_nn: How neural networks learn and process information
dl_fundamentals.dl_intro: Deep learning is a subset of machine learning using neural networks with multiple layers (hence 'deep'). These networks automatically discover the representations needed for detection or classification from raw input.
dl_fundamentals.why_2: Excels at complex tasks like image and language understanding
dl_fundamentals.why_3: Scalable with more data and computational power
dl_fundamentals.neural_networks_intro: A neural network is inspired by biological neurons. It consists of interconnected layers of artificial neurons that process information and learn patterns.
dl_fundamentals.input_layer_desc: Receives raw input data (images, text, numbers, etc.)
dl_fundamentals.hidden_layers_desc: Process information and extract features through non-linear transformations
dl_fundamentals.activation_desc: Activation functions introduce non-linearity, allowing networks to learn complex patterns. Common ones: ReLU, Sigmoid, Tanh.
dl_fundamentals.backpropagation_intro: Backpropagation is the algorithm that trains neural networks by computing gradients and updating weights to minimize loss.
dl_fundamentals.backprop_step_1_desc: Input flows through the network to produce predictions
dl_fundamentals.backprop_step_2_desc: Measure how wrong the predictions are
dl_fundamentals.backprop_step_3_desc: Compute gradients and update weights to reduce loss
dl_fundamentals.architectures_intro: Different architectures are designed for different types of problems. Choose based on your data and task.
dl_fundamentals.cnn_desc: Designed for processing grid-like data. Uses convolutional filters to detect spatial patterns.
dl_fundamentals.rnn_desc: Designed for sequential data with memory. Maintains hidden state as it processes sequences.
dl_fundamentals.transformer_desc: Uses self-attention to process sequences in parallel. Powers modern LLMs like GPT and BERT.
dl_fundamentals.gans_desc: Two networks compete: generator creates data, discriminator judges authenticity. Powerful for generation tasks.
dl_fundamentals.vanishing_gradient_desc: During backpropagation through many layers, gradients can become extremely small, making weight updates ineffective. Solutions: LSTMs, residual connections, careful initialization.
dl_fundamentals.exploding_gradient_desc: Opposite of vanishing gradients: gradients become very large, causing unstable training. Solutions: gradient clipping, normalization techniques.
dl_fundamentals.practice_task: You have a dataset of 10,000 images of handwritten digits. Which architecture would you choose? Why? How would you handle the vanishing gradient problem if using deep networks?
dl_fundamentals.practice_hint: Hint: Consider why CNNs are great for images, and think about modern techniques like batch normalization and skip connections.

nlp_fundamentals.page_title: Natural Language Processing Fundamentals | Master NLP
nlp_fundamentals.page_description: Learn tokenization, text representation, NLP tasks, and how language models power AI systems.
nlp_fundamentals.title: Natural Language Processing Fundamentals
nlp_fundamentals.subtitle: Teaching machines to understand and process human language
nlp_fundamentals.learn_tokenization: Master tokenization and text preprocessing techniques
nlp_fundamentals.learn_representations: Understand text representation methods from BoW to embeddings
nlp_fundamentals.learn_tasks: Learn core NLP tasks and applications
nlp_fundamentals.learn_llm_connection: See how language models build on NLP foundations
nlp_fundamentals.nlp_intro: NLP bridges human language and machine understanding. It's challenging because language has ambiguity, context, idioms, and constant evolution. Modern NLP powers chatbots, translation, sentiment analysis, and LLMs.
nlp_fundamentals.nlp_history_1_desc: Early approaches using hand-coded grammatical rules and patterns
nlp_fundamentals.nlp_history_2_desc: Learning from text data using probability and statistics
nlp_fundamentals.nlp_history_3_desc: Deep learning with neural networks and transformers
nlp_fundamentals.tip_nlp_complexity: Language is complex! The same sentence can mean different things depending on context, culture, and intent. This is why NLP remains an active research area.
nlp_fundamentals.tokenization_intro: Before processing text, we must break it into meaningful units called tokens. This is harder than it seems!
nlp_fundamentals.word_tokenization_desc: Splitting text into individual words. Challenges: 'don't' vs "do not", punctuation handling, contractions.
nlp_fundamentals.subword_tokenization_desc: Breaking words into smaller meaningful units (BPE, WordPiece). Handles rare words and morphology better.
nlp_fundamentals.text_representation_intro: Converting text into numbers that algorithms can process. Different methods capture different aspects of meaning.
nlp_fundamentals.bow_desc: Count occurrences of each word. Simple but loses word order and semantic relationships.
nlp_fundamentals.tfidf_desc: Weights words by importance, reducing impact of common words like 'the'.
nlp_fundamentals.tfidf_pro_2: Better than BoW for many tasks
nlp_fundamentals.embeddings_intro_desc: Dense vectors capturing semantic meaning. Words with similar meanings have similar vectors.
nlp_fundamentals.embeddings_preview: Learn more in the 'Embeddings and Vector Search' tutorial!
nlp_fundamentals.nlp_tasks_intro: NLP tackles many different problems. Here are the most common:
nlp_fundamentals.classification_desc: Assigning categories to text: spam detection, sentiment analysis, topic classification.
nlp_fundamentals.ner_desc: Identifying and classifying named entities: people, organizations, locations, dates.
nlp_fundamentals.sentiment_desc: Determining emotional tone: positive, negative, neutral. Used for reviews, social media monitoring.
nlp_fundamentals.machine_translation_desc: Translating text from one language to another. Evolved from rule-based to statistical to neural approaches.
nlp_fundamentals.language_models_intro: Language models predict the next word given previous context. They're fundamental to modern NLP and LLMs.
nlp_fundamentals.how_lms_work_desc: Language models learn probability distributions P(next_word | previous_words). Given 'The weather is', they predict {sunny: 0.4, rainy: 0.3, ...}.
nlp_fundamentals.tip_language_models: Understanding tokenization helps with prompt engineering. Token limits, token costs, and token efficiency all matter when working with LLMs.
nlp_fundamentals.exercise_1_desc: Compare word-level vs. subword tokenization on a technical text. When would each be preferred?
nlp_fundamentals.exercise_2_desc: Design a prompt for Claude to perform sentiment analysis on customer reviews with explanations.
nlp_fundamentals.exercise_3_desc: Create a prompt to extract structured information (names, dates, locations) from unstructured text.
nlp_fundamentals.quiz_intro: Test your NLP knowledge with our interactive quiz:
nlp_fundamentals.next_steps_desc: Ready to go deeper? Continue with Transformers and Attention to understand modern NLP architectures.

transformers_attention.page_title: Transformers and Attention Mechanisms | Modern AI Architectures
transformers_attention.page_description: Learn about attention mechanisms, transformer architecture, and how they power modern LLMs like Claude and GPT.
transformers_attention.title: Transformers and Attention Mechanisms
transformers_attention.subtitle: The architecture revolutionizing AI and enabling large language models
transformers_attention.learn_attention: Understand attention mechanisms and how models 'focus' on relevant information
transformers_attention.learn_architecture: Master the transformer architecture components and design
transformers_attention.learn_variants: Learn about different transformer variants (BERT, GPT, T5)
transformers_attention.learn_prompting_implications: Understand implications for prompt engineering and context windows
transformers_attention.rnn_limitations_title: Limitations of RNNs and Why Transformers Emerged
transformers_attention.rnn_limitations_intro: Before transformers, RNNs and LSTMs were the state-of-the-art for sequence processing. But they had fundamental limitations that transformers solved.
transformers_attention.sequential_processing_desc: RNNs process sequences one token at a time, preventing parallelization. This makes training slow even on modern GPUs. Transformers process all tokens in parallel.
transformers_attention.long_range_dependency_desc: RNNs struggle with vanishing gradients over long sequences. Transformers use attention to directly relate any two positions, solving this problem.
transformers_attention.tip_rnn_limitation: This is why transformers dominate modern AI. The parallel processing and long-range dependency handling are game-changers for training efficiency and model performance.
transformers_attention.attention_mechanism_intro: Attention allows models to focus on relevant parts of input. It's the key innovation that enables transformers to work so well.
transformers_attention.qkv_desc: Attention uses three components to determine what to focus on:
transformers_attention.query_desc: What am I looking for? (from current position)
transformers_attention.key_desc: What do I contain? (what each position has)
transformers_attention.value_desc: What information should I pass? (actual content to use)
transformers_attention.tip_attention: Attention score = softmax(Query ¬∑ Key^T / sqrt(d)) ¬∑ Value. This mathematical formulation enables learning which positions matter most.
transformers_attention.transformer_architecture_intro: Transformers combine multiple components: encoders, decoders, multi-head attention, and feed-forward networks. Understanding each part is key.
transformers_attention.encoder_desc: Processes input sequence with attention and feed-forward networks. Outputs rich representations of the input.
transformers_attention.decoder_desc: Generates output sequence using encoder representations and self-attention. Uses causal masking to prevent cheating (looking at future tokens).
transformers_attention.multihead_attention_desc: Multiple attention heads in parallel capture different relationship types. Head 1 might focus on syntax, Head 2 on semantics, etc.
transformers_attention.positional_encoding_desc: Transformers don't inherently know token order (unlike RNNs). Positional encodings add position information so the model learns sequence order matters.
transformers_attention.tip_positional_encoding: This explains why prompt order matters! Positional encodings mean the same tokens in different orders create different representations.
transformers_attention.model_variants_intro: Different transformer variants are optimized for different tasks. Knowing the differences helps you choose the right tool.
transformers_attention.bert_desc: Bidirectional - can see full context from both directions. Masked language modeling: randomly mask tokens and predict them. Excellent for understanding tasks.
transformers_attention.bert_uses: Classification, NER, question answering, semantic similarity
transformers_attention.gpt_desc: Autoregressive - predicts next token given previous tokens. Causal masking prevents looking at future. Foundation for ChatGPT, Claude, etc.
transformers_attention.gpt_uses: Text generation, completion, conversation, code generation
transformers_attention.t5_desc: Combines both - encoder for understanding, decoder for generation. Text-to-text framework treats all tasks uniformly.
transformers_attention.prompting_implications_intro: Understanding transformer architecture directly informs best practices for prompting. Context window, token positioning, and attention patterns all matter.
transformers_attention.context_window_desc: Attention is O(n¬≤) complexity. A 4K token context uses ~16M operations; 32K tokens uses ~1B. This is why context windows are limited and longer contexts are more expensive.
transformers_attention.token_positioning_desc: Positional encodings mean token position affects its meaning. Strategic placement of important info affects model focus and reasoning.
transformers_attention.prompt_placement_desc: Instructions, examples, and key information placement matters. First position gets strong positional encoding; middle positions are 'lost in the middle'.
transformers_attention.tip_prompting_implications: Put your most important instructions at the beginning or end of prompts, not in the middle. Use explicit structure (sections, formatting) to help attention mechanisms.
transformers_attention.exercise_1_desc: Use an online attention visualization tool to see which tokens attend to which others in a sentence. Explain the attention patterns.
transformers_attention.exercise_2_desc: Given a 10,000-word document and a question, design a prompt strategy that works within a 4K token window using transformer insights.
transformers_attention.exercise_3_desc: Test the same prompt with critical instructions at the beginning vs. middle vs. end. Document performance differences.
transformers_attention.quiz_intro: Test your understanding of transformers and attention:
transformers_attention.next_steps_desc: Ready for practical applications? Learn about Embeddings and Vector Search to see how semantic understanding powers RAG systems.

embeddings_vector_search.page_title: Embeddings and Vector Search | Semantic AI
embeddings_vector_search.page_description: Learn how embeddings represent semantic meaning, similarity metrics, and vector databases for building intelligent search systems.
embeddings_vector_search.title: Embeddings and Vector Search
embeddings_vector_search.subtitle: Understanding semantic similarity and building intelligent search systems
embeddings_vector_search.learn_embeddings: Understand embeddings as dense vector representations of meaning
embeddings_vector_search.learn_similarity: Master similarity metrics for comparing semantic meaning
embeddings_vector_search.learn_vector_db: Learn about vector databases and their role in RAG systems
embeddings_vector_search.learn_applications: Explore real-world applications: search, recommendations, clustering
embeddings_vector_search.embeddings_intro: Embeddings are dense vectors of numbers that represent the semantic meaning of words, sentences, or documents. Unlike sparse BoW representations, embeddings capture semantic relationships mathematically.
embeddings_vector_search.semantic_meaning: Example: 'king' - 'man' + 'woman' ‚âà 'queen'. This vector arithmetic reflects semantic relationships learned from training data.
embeddings_vector_search.tip_embeddings: Modern embeddings (BERT, sentence-transformers, OpenAI's text-embedding-3) are trained on massive datasets and capture rich semantic information. Use pre-trained models rather than training your own.
embeddings_vector_search.cosine_similarity_desc: Measures the angle between two vectors (-1 to +1). Captures semantic similarity independent of magnitude. Most popular for embeddings (ranges 0-1 after normalization).
embeddings_vector_search.euclidean_distance_desc: Geometric distance between points in vector space. Considers magnitude, so raw embeddings may need normalization first. Good when magnitude matters.
embeddings_vector_search.vector_db_intro: Vector databases are specialized systems for storing and querying embeddings efficiently. They solve the k-nearest-neighbor problem at scale with approximate algorithms.
embeddings_vector_search.vdb_benefit_1: Efficient similarity search - find similar items in milliseconds even with millions of embeddings
embeddings_vector_search.vdb_benefit_2: Metadata filtering - combine vector search with structured data filters
embeddings_vector_search.vdb_benefit_3: Real-time updates - add/modify embeddings without rebuilding indexes
embeddings_vector_search.tip_vector_db: Popular vector databases: Pinecone (managed), Weaviate (open-source), Chroma (simple), Milvus (scalable). Choose based on your deployment needs and scale.
embeddings_vector_search.semantic_search_desc: Find content by meaning, not keywords. Query 'how to fix a leaky faucet' matches 'repair dripping tap' even with no keyword overlap.
embeddings_vector_search.recommendations_desc: Find similar items in embedding space. Amazon uses this to show 'customers who viewed X also viewed Y'.
embeddings_vector_search.clustering_desc: Group similar items by proximity in embedding space. Useful for organizing content, topic detection, and community detection.
embeddings_vector_search.next_steps_desc: Apply embeddings to RAG systems! Learn how to combine embeddings with LLMs for knowledge-augmented AI.

computer_vision_fundamentals.page_description: Learn how images are processed by machines, convolutional neural networks, and computer vision tasks.
computer_vision_fundamentals.title: Computer Vision Fundamentals
computer_vision_fundamentals.subtitle: Teaching machines to see and understand visual content
computer_vision_fundamentals.learn_images: Understand how images are represented as data for machines
computer_vision_fundamentals.learn_cnns: Master Convolutional Neural Networks and their design
computer_vision_fundamentals.learn_tasks: Learn core computer vision tasks: classification, detection, segmentation
computer_vision_fundamentals.learn_transfer: Understand transfer learning and pre-trained vision models
computer_vision_fundamentals.images_intro: Digital images are matrices of numbers. Color images have 3 channels (RGB), grayscale have 1. A 224√ó224 image = 150,528 input features. This high dimensionality is why traditional ML struggles.
computer_vision_fundamentals.pixel_info: Pixels: smallest units, each containing intensity values (0-255 for standard images)
computer_vision_fundamentals.channels_info: Channels: RGB has 3 (Red, Green, Blue), grayscale has 1
computer_vision_fundamentals.resolution_info: Resolution: 1080p = 1920√ó1080, 4K = 3840√ó2160. Higher resolution = more features = slower processing
computer_vision_fundamentals.cnn_intro: CNNs are designed specifically for image data. They use convolutional filters to detect local features at different positions and scales.
computer_vision_fundamentals.conv_desc: Slide filters across images to detect features (edges, textures, patterns). Parameter sharing drastically reduces model size compared to fully connected layers.
computer_vision_fundamentals.pooling_desc: Downsampling to reduce dimensionality and provide translation invariance. Max pooling takes the maximum value in a window.
computer_vision_fundamentals.fc_desc: Final classification layers. Early layers extract features; late layers use features for classification.
computer_vision_fundamentals.classification_cv: Assigning a single label to an image. Example: dog vs. cat. Metrics: accuracy, top-k accuracy.
computer_vision_fundamentals.detection_desc: Finding multiple objects and their bounding boxes. Example: autonomous driving. Metric: mAP (mean Average Precision).
computer_vision_fundamentals.segmentation_desc: Pixel-level classification. Semantic segmentation labels each pixel with a class. Instance segmentation separates instances of the same class.
computer_vision_fundamentals.transfer_intro: Training a CNN from scratch requires millions of images. Transfer learning leverages pre-trained models, dramatically reducing data and compute needs.
computer_vision_fundamentals.tl_benefit_1: Pre-trained on ImageNet (14M images, 1000 classes) capture generalizable features
computer_vision_fundamentals.tl_benefit_2: Fine-tune on small target datasets (100-1000 images) for strong performance
computer_vision_fundamentals.tl_benefit_3: Popular models: ResNet, EfficientNet, Vision Transformer (ViT)
computer_vision_fundamentals.next_steps_desc: Computer vision pairs with language in multimodal models. Learn about Claude's vision capabilities for practical applications!

llm_finetuning.page_description: Learn when, why, and how to fine-tune LLMs using techniques like LoRA and QLoRA for domain-specific tasks.
llm_finetuning.title: Fine-Tuning Large Language Models
llm_finetuning.subtitle: Customize powerful models for your specific use cases
llm_finetuning.learn_data: Prepare data correctly for fine-tuning without data leakage
llm_finetuning.learn_training: Understand training dynamics, hyperparameters, and debugging
llm_finetuning.when_to_finetune: When to Fine-Tune vs. Prompt Engineering
llm_finetuning.intro: Fine-tuning is powerful but not always necessary. Understand the tradeoffs between prompting (flexible, immediate) and fine-tuning (specialized, requires data).
llm_finetuning.use_case_1: Domain-specific language or style (legal documents, medical terminology, brand voice)
llm_finetuning.use_case_2: Consistent output format requirements (JSON, structured data, specific templates)
llm_finetuning.use_case_3: Improved performance on repeated tasks where prompting plateaus
llm_finetuning.lora_desc: Train small low-rank matrices instead of full weights (ŒîW = B¬∑A where B‚àà‚Ñù^{d√ór}, A‚àà‚Ñù^{r√ók}). Reduces trainable parameters by 100x while maintaining performance. r (rank) typically 8-32.
llm_finetuning.qlora_desc: Combines LoRA with 4-bit quantization. Enables fine-tuning 65B parameter models on a single consumer GPU (RTX 4090). Trade-off: slightly lower quality vs. massive efficiency.
llm_finetuning.data_intro: Quality and quantity matter. A thousand well-curated examples often beat 100k poor examples. Format matters too - use instruction-input-output triplets.
llm_finetuning.data_point_1: Quality > Quantity: 1,000 hand-crafted examples > 100,000 noisy examples
llm_finetuning.data_point_2: Format matters: Instruction-Input-Output structure; clear separation between components
llm_finetuning.data_point_3: Diversity: Cover task variations; include edge cases; represent different use patterns
llm_finetuning.next_steps_desc: Ready to make models remember? Learn about RAG as an alternative (or complementary) approach to keep knowledge dynamic.

rag_systems.page_description: Learn RAG architecture, retrieval strategies, chunking, and how to build systems that combine search with language generation.
rag_systems.title: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)
rag_systems.subtitle: Build intelligent systems that retrieve knowledge and generate answers
rag_systems.learn_chunking: Master document chunking strategies for semantic coherence
rag_systems.learn_retrieval: Learn dense, sparse, and hybrid retrieval approaches
rag_systems.learn_optimization: Optimize RAG systems for quality and performance
rag_systems.rag_intro: Retrieval-Augmented Generation combines a retriever (finds relevant context) with a generator (LLM) to answer questions grounded in knowledge bases. Dynamic alternative to fine-tuning.
rag_systems.rag_pipeline: RAG Pipeline: 1) Embed and index knowledge documents 2) User query ‚Üí embedding ‚Üí vector search ‚Üí retrieve top-k chunks 3) Chunk + query ‚Üí LLM ‚Üí grounded answer with citations.
rag_systems.rag_benefit_1_desc: Update knowledge instantly without retraining. News, documentation, or proprietary data changes are reflected immediately.
rag_systems.rag_benefit_2_desc: No training cost, only inference cost. Run on consumption. Fine-tuning requires compute upfront.
rag_systems.rag_benefit_3_desc: Citations show which sources informed the answer. Users can verify claims. Fine-tuning knowledge is embedded and opaque.
rag_systems.chunking_intro: Breaking documents into semantic chunks is critical. Too small loses context; too large dilutes relevance signals.
rag_systems.chunk_point_1: Fixed-size chunking: Simple but may break semantic units. Example: 500 tokens with 50-token overlap.
rag_systems.chunk_point_2: Semantic chunking: Respect natural boundaries (sentences, paragraphs). Better semantic coherence but variable sizes.
rag_systems.chunk_point_3: Document structure: Use headers, lists, tables as boundaries. Requires structured input (Markdown, HTML).
rag_systems.dense_desc: Embedding-based similarity search. Captures semantic meaning: 'car' matches 'automobile'. Best for paraphrased queries.
rag_systems.sparse_desc: Keyword-based (BM25, TF-IDF). Exact lexical matching. Best for named entities, codes, specific terms.
rag_systems.hybrid_desc: Combine dense and sparse using reciprocal rank fusion. Gets both semantics and keywords. Best of both worlds.
rag_systems.next_steps_desc: RAG + Fine-Tuning aren't mutually exclusive! Many systems use both for maximum power. Learn about RAG + fine-tuned models for best results.

ai_ethics_responsible.page_title: AI Ethics and Responsible AI | Fair and Safe AI
ai_ethics_responsible.page_description: Learn about bias, fairness, privacy, interpretability, and responsible AI governance for building fair and trustworthy systems.
ai_ethics_responsible.title: AI Ethics and Responsible AI Development
ai_ethics_responsible.subtitle: Build fair, safe, transparent, and accountable AI systems
ai_ethics_responsible.learn_bias: Understand bias sources and mitigation strategies
ai_ethics_responsible.learn_privacy: Protect user data with privacy-preserving techniques
ai_ethics_responsible.learn_governance: Understand governance frameworks and responsible deployment
ai_ethics_responsible.ethics_intro: AI systems affect real lives. Biased hiring algorithms discriminate. Biased medical diagnosis tools miss conditions in underrepresented groups. Responsible AI development is not optional‚Äîit's essential.
ai_ethics_responsible.real_example: Real example: Amazon's hiring algorithm learned to discriminate against women because their training data reflected historical bias in tech. The system reinforced the problem it should have solved.
ai_ethics_responsible.historical_desc: Training data reflects past discrimination. If historical hiring favored men, model learns to prefer men. Solution: acknowledge bias, collect representative data, use fairness constraints.
ai_ethics_responsible.data_bias_desc: Representation bias: underrepresented groups in data. Measurement bias: proxies for protected attributes (zip code as proxy for race). Solution: balanced sampling, diverse data collection.
ai_ethics_responsible.fairness_desc: Multiple definitions exist: demographic parity (equal outcomes), equal opportunity (equal true positive rates), etc. They're mathematically incompatible‚Äîchoose based on context and values.
ai_ethics_responsible.privacy_desc: Models memorize training data. Membership inference attacks detect if someone was in training data. Solution: differential privacy, federated learning, data minimization.
ai_ethics_responsible.differential_desc: Mathematical framework adding noise during training. Guarantees: individual records protected even with model access. Trade-off: slight accuracy loss for strong privacy.
ai_ethics_responsible.transparency_intro: Black box models are risky. Interpretability techniques and transparency matter for trust and compliance.
ai_ethics_responsible.transparency_point_1: Model cards: document architecture, training data, performance metrics, known limitations, intended use
ai_ethics_responsible.transparency_point_2: Interpretability: SHAP/LIME for explaining individual predictions; attention visualization for transformers
ai_ethics_responsible.transparency_point_3: User communication: explain capabilities and limitations clearly; don't mislead about AI capabilities
ai_ethics_responsible.next_steps_desc: Ethics applies to all tutorials! Every AI system should consider bias, fairness, and responsible deployment. This is ongoing‚Äîstay informed as the field evolves.

prompt_optimization.page_title: Optimizing Prompts for Performance | Learn Prompt Engineering
prompt_optimization.page_description: Master techniques to make your prompts faster, cheaper, and more reliable through token optimization, caching, and error prevention.
prompt_optimization.title: Optimizing Prompts for Performance
prompt_optimization.subtitle: Master techniques to make your prompts faster, cheaper, and more reliable
prompt_optimization.learn_reduce: Reduce token usage and costs with targeted prompting
prompt_optimization.learn_faster: Speed up responses with caching and prompt optimization
prompt_optimization.learn_reliability: Build reliable prompts with error prevention strategies
prompt_optimization.learn_caching: Implement prompt caching for expensive contexts
prompt_optimization.cost_desc: Reduce API costs by optimizing token usage and eliminating redundancy
prompt_optimization.speed_desc: Faster responses through caching and efficient prompt structure
prompt_optimization.reliability_desc: More consistent, predictable outputs through error prevention
prompt_optimization.tokens_intro: Tokens are the basic units of text that AI models process. Every word, punctuation mark, and space consumes tokens. Optimizing token usage reduces costs and speeds up responses.
prompt_optimization.tokens_alert: 1,000 tokens ‚âà 750 words. Reducing prompt size by 20% can significantly lower costs.
prompt_optimization.token_waste_example: Unnecessary words, filler text, and verbose phrasing consume tokens without adding value.
prompt_optimization.token_efficient_example: Clear, concise instructions that communicate the same intent with fewer tokens.
prompt_optimization.strategy_redundant_example: Instead of 'Please, if you would be so kind, could you...' use 'Please...' or just state the request directly.
prompt_optimization.strategy_abbreviations_example: Use ‚Üí instead of 'leads to', & instead of 'and', w/ instead of 'with'.
prompt_optimization.strategy_output_length_example: Add constraints like 'Respond in exactly 3 bullet points' or 'Keep response under 100 tokens'.
prompt_optimization.strategy_extract_example: Instead of asking for full explanations, request specific data: 'List only the 3 most important points'.
prompt_optimization.caching_intro: Prompt caching allows you to cache large portions of your prompt (like documentation, code examples, or system instructions) and reuse them across multiple requests. Only the new user input is processed as new tokens.
prompt_optimization.caching_best_for: Best for: Large system prompts, extensive code context, documentation references, or repeated analysis of different data against the same context.
prompt_optimization.caching_practice_1: Put static content (system instructions, documentation) early in your prompt
prompt_optimization.caching_practice_2: Keep the static portion large (>1KB) for meaningful cost savings
prompt_optimization.caching_practice_3: Use caching for recurring tasks with the same context
prompt_optimization.caching_practice_4: Monitor cache hit rates to measure savings
prompt_optimization.concise_tips: Keep it brief. Answer in under 50 words. Skip explanations.
prompt_optimization.batching_alert: Batching reduces API calls and costs. Process multiple items in a single request whenever possible.
prompt_optimization.output_format_good: Good: 'Return as JSON: {analysis: string, confidence: 0-100, next_steps: string[]}'
prompt_optimization.edge_case_example: If input is empty, return 'No data provided'. If invalid format, explain what's wrong.
prompt_optimization.validation_example: If the response contains undefined variables, ask for clarification instead of proceeding.
prompt_optimization.checklist_before_sending: Use this checklist before sending your prompt:
prompt_optimization.checklist_1: Are token counts reasonable for the task?
prompt_optimization.checklist_2: Did I remove unnecessary words or filler text?
prompt_optimization.checklist_3: Is the output format clearly specified?
prompt_optimization.checklist_5: Could I use caching for static content?
prompt_optimization.checklist_7: Is the response length controlled and specific?

multi_agent_systems.page_description: Build complex systems with multiple AI agents working together to solve advanced problems.
multi_agent_systems.title: Multi-Agent Systems
multi_agent_systems.subtitle: Build complex systems with multiple AI agents working together.
multi_agent_systems.intro: A multi-agent system consists of multiple specialized AI agents working together to solve complex problems that a single agent couldn't handle as effectively.
multi_agent_systems.single_desc: One agent tries to do everything:
multi_agent_systems.single_1: Jack of all trades, master of none
multi_agent_systems.pattern_1_desc: Agents work in a linear sequence, each processing the previous agent's output
multi_agent_systems.pattern_2_desc: Multiple agents work simultaneously, then results are combined
multi_agent_systems.pattern_3_desc: Agents critique and improve each other's work in cycles
multi_agent_systems.pattern_4_desc: A coordinator agent manages and delegates to specialized workers
multi_agent_systems.interface_1_desc: Make agents output in predictable formats:
multi_agent_systems.interface_1_example: Agent prompt: "Return results as JSON with fields: summary, confidence, next_steps"
multi_agent_systems.interface_2_desc: Explicitly state what the next agent needs:
multi_agent_systems.do_1: ‚úì Give each agent a clear, specific role
multi_agent_systems.real_world_intro: A complete multi-agent system for creating high-quality blog posts:
multi_agent_systems.result_message: Result: High-quality content in 1-2 minutes that would take a human 2-3 hours!
